metadata.description: Semantic chunks from CBC UpToDate reference covering all major CBC interpretation topics

chunks.title: Phlebotomy and Blood Collection Technique
chunks.text: Collection of the blood samples should be performed by a trained phlebotomist or experienced member of the health care team. It is very common to observe hemolyzed blood samples due to small gauge needles or tourniquets that are too tight, leading to shearing of red blood cells (RBCs). Hemolysis during phlebotomy spuriously decreases the RBC count, hematocrit, and may falsely elevate potassium. Proper technique requires: avoiding small-gauge needles (<23G), limiting tourniquet time (<1 minute), and gently mixing the collected tube by inversion 8-10 times to prevent clotting without causing hemolysis.

chunks.title: Collection Tube and Anticoagulant
chunks.text: Samples to be used for a CBC should be collected into a tube with an anticoagulant solution such as EDTA (ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid; 'purple top' tube) or sodium citrate ('blue top' tube). EDTA may cause platelet clumping or satellitism in some patients, leading to pseudothrombocytopenia. Platelet aggregates can also falsely increase the white blood cell (WBC) count. If EDTA-related pseudothrombocytopenia is suspected, repeat the sample in a citrate (blue-top) or heparin tube. The ratio of anticoagulant in a tube to blood is carefully calibrated: underfilling leads to overexposure to EDTA (falsely low platelet count, altered MCV), while overfilling can lead to clotting and inaccurate results.

chunks.title: Storage Temperature and Duration
chunks.text: Blood samples should be kept at room temperature if the specimen will be analyzed within 24 hours of collection. Samples should be refrigerated (4°C) if the analysis is to occur up to 72 hours after collection. Freezing of blood samples must be absolutely avoided; freezing will cause cells to lyse, leading to completely inaccurate values. Blood samples exposed to heat will cause RBCs to fragment, producing significant anisocytosis and bizarre microcytes resembling blood samples seen in burn victims. Samples greater than 72 hours old should not be used for CBC testing as they can show spurious results including elevated MCV and altered platelet morphology. Blood films should be prepared within eight hours of sample collection; with longer storage, cells become pyknotic with altered morphology that can lead to spurious identification of dysplasia in WBCs.

chunks.title: Rule of Threes - Specimen Integrity Check
chunks.text: In a healthy individual, the rule of threes should be met: three times the RBC count should equal the hemoglobin (Hgb = RBC × 3), and three times the hemoglobin should equal the hematocrit (HCT = Hgb × 3). If the rule is not met, one of two possibilities exists: the results may be spurious (in an otherwise healthy individual) indicating a sample quality problem, or a true hematologic condition may be present. A deviation greater than 10% from the expected value should prompt review. Common causes of Rule of Three violations include: hemolysis of sample, underfilled collection tube, cold agglutinin (affecting RBC count), lipemia (affecting hemoglobin), or a true underlying hematologic disorder.

chunks.title: MCHC as Quality Control Parameter
chunks.text: Very high MCHC values typically reflect spherocytosis or RBC agglutination, but are also commonly spurious results. High MCHC can result from: (1) Spuriously low RBC count due to a cold agglutinin, which causes several agglutinated RBCs to be counted as a single RBC; (2) Spuriously increased hemoglobin, which can result from a very high WBC count, lipemia, a monoclonal protein, or a hemoglobin-based oxygen carrier (HBOC), all of which produce turbidity in the colorimetric hemoglobin assay; (3) Sample hemolysis releasing free hemoglobin. A very low MCHC (less than 28 g/dL) may also be spurious and can be caused by hyperglycemia creating osmotic imbalance. MCHC is generally one of the most stable CBC parameters in a healthy individual, so deviations should prompt quality review.

chunks.title: RBC Count, Hemoglobin, and Hematocrit
chunks.text: RBC count is the number of RBCs per microL of blood. An elevated RBC count indicates polycythemia (reactive or neoplastic) or thalassemia. A decreased RBC count typically indicates anemia. Hemoglobin (Hb) is the concentration of Hb in whole blood, in grams/deciliter (g/dL). Increased Hb may be due to polycythemia (reactive or neoplastic) or may occur with dehydration. Decreased Hb indicates anemia. Normal adult ranges: males 13.5-17.5 g/dL, females 12.0-15.5 g/dL. The hematocrit (HCT) is the packed volume of blood made up of RBCs, expressed as a percentage. An increased HCT indicates polycythemia (reactive or neoplastic) or dehydration. Normal adult ranges: males 41-53%, females 36-46%.

chunks.title: MCV - Mean Corpuscular Volume
chunks.text: Mean corpuscular volume (MCV) is the average volume (size) of the RBCs. Normal range is 80-100 fL. Anemia is classified based on whether the MCV is low (microcytic, MCV <80 fL), normal (normocytic, 80-100 fL), or elevated (macrocytic, MCV >100 fL). MCV should not significantly vary in a healthy adult. Changes outside a laboratory reference interval or a change from a person's baseline that is greater than 5 fL in the same laboratory using the same instrument should prompt evaluation. A low MCV prompts evaluation for iron deficiency, thalassemia, anemia of chronic disease, or sideroblastic anemia. A high MCV prompts evaluation for B12 deficiency, folate deficiency, hypothyroidism, liver disease, medications, or MDS.

chunks.title: RDW - Red Cell Distribution Width
chunks.text: Red cell distribution width (RDW) is a measure of the variation in MCV, reflected in the degree of anisocytosis on the peripheral blood smear. Normal range is 11.5-14.5%. If all parameters of the CBC are normal, an abnormal RDW should not prompt significant workup — a repeat blood draw and CBC can be performed instead. The RDW is most useful in patients with microcytic anemia: an elevated RDW is consistent with iron deficiency anemia (IDA) and a normal RDW is consistent with anemia of chronic disease/inflammation (ACD/AI) or thalassemia trait. RDW has been proposed as a tool to distinguish iron deficiency (elevated RDW) from thalassemia trait (normal RDW) in samples with low MCV. However, thalassemia trait can also cause an elevated RDW, so this distinction is imperfect. A very elevated RDW can also be seen in transfused anemia, myelodysplastic syndromes, and hemoglobinopathies.

chunks.title: MCH and MCHC - Hemoglobin Content Indices
chunks.text: MCH (mean corpuscular hemoglobin) is the average hemoglobin content in the RBC population. MCHC (mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration) is the average hemoglobin concentration per RBC, in g/dL. Normal MCHC: 32-36 g/dL. In the absence of anemia, a slightly abnormal MCH or MCHC should not prompt further evaluation. A low MCH or low MCHC indicates decreased hemoglobin content and is typically reflected in hypochromia on the peripheral blood smear, seen in iron deficiency and disorders of globin synthesis (thalassemia). Very low MCHC values are typical of iron deficiency anemia. A high MCHC (>36 g/dL) is typically seen with hereditary spherocytosis, but is more commonly a spurious result due to hemolysis, cold agglutinin, lipemia, or very high WBC count.

chunks.title: Reticulocyte Count and Production Index
chunks.text: Reticulocytes are identified by the absence of a nucleus and the presence of measurable RNA. The reticulocyte count provides information about bone marrow erythropoietic activity. Normal range: 0.5-2.5%. An elevated reticulocyte count (reticulocytosis) suggests active bone marrow production compensating for anemia — seen in hemolytic anemia, blood loss recovery, or response to treatment. A low reticulocyte count in the setting of anemia suggests hypoproliferative anemia (bone marrow not responding adequately). The Reticulocyte Production Index (RPI) = (Reticulocyte% × Patient HCT/45) / Maturation time. Maturation time is 1.0 days at HCT≥35%, 1.5 days at HCT 25-34%, and 2.0 days at HCT<25%. RPI <2 indicates inadequate marrow response (hypoproliferative); RPI ≥2 indicates hyperproliferative response consistent with hemolysis or blood loss.

chunks.title: Platelet Count - Normal Values and Evaluation
chunks.text: The platelet count is the number of platelets per microL of blood. Normal range: 150-400 × 10⁹/L. A decreased platelet count (thrombocytopenia) may reflect platelet destruction, sequestration, or ineffective thrombopoiesis. The first step in evaluating thrombocytopenia is to rule out pseudothrombocytopenia (EDTA-induced platelet clumping); if suspected, repeat in citrate tube and examine blood smear for platelet aggregates. An elevated platelet count (thrombocytosis) may be seen in reactive and neoplastic conditions. Critical platelet values: <20 × 10⁹/L risk of spontaneous bleeding; <50 × 10⁹/L increased bleeding risk with trauma; >1000 × 10⁹/L risk of both thrombosis and paradoxical bleeding.

chunks.title: MPV - Mean Platelet Volume
chunks.text: The mean platelet volume (MPV) is the average platelet size in femtoliters (fL). Normal range: 7.5-12.5 fL. MPV should be evaluated in the context of the platelet count. High MPV indicates active bone marrow production of platelets, as in immune thrombocytopenia (ITP), or inherited platelet disorders (Bernard-Soulier syndrome). A sequential increase in MPV over time can indicate megakaryocytic regeneration, such as recovery from a hypoplastic or aplastic state. Low MPV indicates bone marrow suppression, as in aplastic anemia. A low MPV may also be seen with Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome (WAS). Under normal circumstances, there is an inverse relationship between platelet size and number. MPV is affected by prolonged EDTA storage (raises MPV) and should ideally be analyzed within 2 hours of collection.

chunks.title: WBC Count and Differential Overview
chunks.text: The WBC count is the number of WBCs per microL of blood (normal: 4.5-11.0 × 10⁹/L). Neutrophils make up the majority of WBCs and abnormal WBC counts are often (but not always) due to abnormal neutrophil counts. A decreased WBC (leukopenia) may be seen in infections, bone marrow disorders, splenomegaly, and autoimmune conditions. An elevated WBC (leukocytosis) may be seen in non-neoplastic conditions (especially infections) and certain cancers. When the WBC count is abnormal, a differential should be obtained to enumerate which type of WBC is decreased or increased. The five-part differential includes: neutrophils (40-75%), lymphocytes (20-45%), monocytes (2-10%), eosinophils (1-6%), basophils (0-1%). Many analyzers also report a seven-part differential including immature granulocytes and nucleated RBCs.

chunks.title: Anemia Classification by MCV
chunks.text: Anemia is defined as hemoglobin below normal for sex: <13.5 g/dL in males, <12.0 g/dL in females. Severity: mild (Hgb 10-12/13 g/dL), moderate (Hgb 8-10 g/dL), severe (Hgb <8 g/dL). Anemia classification by MCV: Microcytic anemia (MCV <80 fL) suggests iron deficiency, thalassemia, anemia of chronic disease, sideroblastic anemia, or lead poisoning. Normocytic anemia (MCV 80-100 fL) suggests acute blood loss, hemolytic anemia, anemia of chronic disease/inflammation, aplastic anemia, or renal disease. Macrocytic anemia (MCV >100 fL) suggests B12/folate deficiency, liver disease, hypothyroidism, medications (hydroxyurea, methotrexate, AZT), or myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS). The RDW helps distinguish causes within the microcytic category: elevated RDW favors iron deficiency, normal RDW favors thalassemia trait.

chunks.title: Iron Deficiency Anemia - Diagnosis
chunks.text: Iron deficiency anemia (IDA) is the most common cause of microcytic anemia worldwide. CBC findings: low MCV (<80 fL), low MCHC, elevated RDW, low MCH, hypochromia on blood smear. Key diagnostic tests: serum ferritin (most sensitive, <30 ng/mL is diagnostic), serum iron (low), TIBC/transferrin (elevated), transferrin saturation (<20%). The CBC distinction between IDA and thalassemia trait: elevated RDW favors IDA while normal RDW favors thalassemia, but this is imperfect as both can have elevated RDW. In IDA, the reticulocyte count is typically low unless there is concurrent active bleeding stimulating erythropoiesis. Treatment is with iron supplementation; response monitored by reticulocyte count rise (within 7-10 days) and Hgb improvement (1 g/dL per week expected).

chunks.title: Thalassemia - CBC Patterns
chunks.text: Thalassemia trait (carrier state) produces mild to moderate microcytic anemia. Beta-thalassemia trait: low MCV, mildly low Hgb, normal or mildly elevated RDW, characteristic normal or slightly elevated RBC count (unlike IDA where RBC is low). HbA2 >3.5% on hemoglobin electrophoresis is diagnostic of beta-thalassemia trait. Alpha-thalassemia trait: presents similarly with low MCV and normal Hb electrophoresis (HbA2 is normal — diagnosis often by exclusion or genetic testing). Target cells, basophilic stippling, and hypochromic microcytes are seen on peripheral smear. The Mentzer index (MCV/RBC): <13 suggests thalassemia, >13 suggests iron deficiency. However, ferritin should always be checked first to exclude concurrent iron deficiency.

chunks.title: Macrocytic Anemia - B12 and Folate Deficiency
chunks.text: Macrocytic anemia (MCV >100 fL) most commonly results from vitamin B12 or folate deficiency, producing megaloblastic anemia. CBC findings: elevated MCV (often >110 fL in severe deficiency), elevated RDW, hypersegmented neutrophils (>5 lobes in >5% of neutrophils — hallmark finding), large oval macrocytes (macro-ovalocytes) on smear, pancytopenia in severe cases. Causes: B12 deficiency from pernicious anemia (anti-intrinsic factor antibodies), gastric surgery, vegan diet, malabsorption. Folate deficiency from poor diet, malabsorption, alcoholism, pregnancy, medications (methotrexate, trimethoprim). Other causes of macrocytosis: hypothyroidism (check TSH), liver disease (check LFTs), medications (hydroxyurea, AZT, azathioprine), MDS, reticulocytosis (reticulocytes are larger than mature RBCs).

chunks.title: Normocytic Anemia - Approach
chunks.text: Normocytic anemia (MCV 80-100 fL) requires evaluation of the reticulocyte count to stratify: (1) Hyperproliferative (elevated reticulocytes, RPI ≥2): suggests active hemolysis or acute blood loss. Proceed with hemolytic workup: LDH (elevated), bilirubin (elevated unconjugated), haptoglobin (decreased), direct Coombs test, peripheral smear. (2) Hypoproliferative (low/normal reticulocytes, RPI <2): suggests bone marrow underproduction. Consider anemia of chronic disease/inflammation (most common), chronic kidney disease (check BUN/creatinine — EPO deficiency), aplastic anemia (pancytopenia + low reticulocytes), hypothyroidism, nutritional deficiency with concurrent cause, or marrow infiltration/MDS. Anemia of chronic disease features: normal or high ferritin, low serum iron, low TIBC, normal MCV.

chunks.title: Hemolytic Anemia - Classification and Diagnosis
chunks.text: Hemolytic anemia is classified as intravascular (within circulation) or extravascular (reticuloendothelial system). Key laboratory markers: elevated LDH (nonspecific), elevated unconjugated bilirubin, decreased haptoglobin (most specific for hemolysis — often undetectable), elevated reticulocyte count. Intravascular hemolysis additionally shows hemoglobinuria (dark urine), hemoglobinemia (pink plasma), and hemosiderinuria after several days. Causes: autoimmune (AIHA — positive direct Coombs), hereditary spherocytosis, G6PD deficiency, sickle cell disease, TTP/HUS (schistocytes, thrombocytopenia), microangiopathic hemolysis, paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH), malaria, mechanical heart valves. Peripheral blood smear is essential: spherocytes suggest AIHA or HS; schistocytes suggest TMA; sickle cells confirm SCD.

chunks.title: Anemia of Chronic Disease and Inflammation
chunks.text: Anemia of chronic disease/anemia of inflammation (ACD/AI) is one of the most common causes of anemia in hospitalized patients. It is associated with chronic infections, autoimmune diseases, malignancy, and organ failure. Pathophysiology: elevated hepcidin (acute phase reactant) leads to iron sequestration in macrophages, reducing iron available for erythropoiesis. CBC features: typically normocytic (MCV 80-100 fL) or mildly microcytic, low reticulocyte count. Key labs: ferritin normal or elevated (acute phase protein), serum iron low, TIBC low (distinguishes from iron deficiency where TIBC is elevated), transferrin saturation low. Treatment is directed at the underlying condition. EPO-stimulating agents may be used in chronic kidney disease or chemotherapy-related anemia.

chunks.title: Neutrophilia - Mechanisms and Definition
chunks.text: Neutrophilia is defined as an absolute neutrophil count (ANC) greater than 7.7 × 10⁹/L (some laboratories use 8.0). It may be due to increased bone marrow production and/or demargination of peripheral blood neutrophils. The peripheral WBC count is only a crude reflection of neutrophil production, since the vast majority of neutrophils are present in the bone marrow. Approximately half of circulating neutrophils are reversibly adherent to the endothelium ('marginated'), so processes that increase neutrophil demargination (catecholamines, exercise, corticosteroids) can rapidly elevate the WBC count within minutes without increased marrow production. Sustained neutrophilia (>1-2 weeks) is more likely to represent true increased production.

chunks.title: Reactive Causes of Neutrophilia
chunks.text: The most common cause of neutrophilia is bacterial infection. Neutrophilia with a left shift (increased band neutrophils >5%) is commonly seen with acute bacterial infections. The blood smear may reveal toxic granulations, Döhle bodies, and cytoplasmic vacuoles in neutrophils. WBC count may rise as high as 100,000/microL in severe infections ('leukemoid reaction'). COVID-19 can also cause neutrophilia. Other reactive causes: inflammation (RA, IBD, vasculitis), medications (corticosteroids — most common drug cause via demargination and marrow release; G-CSF, lithium, epinephrine, all-trans retinoic acid). Physiologic causes: exercise and stress (rapid demargination), pregnancy, asplenia/post-splenectomy (moderate neutrophilia with thrombocytosis and Howell-Jolly bodies), smoking (raises WBC ~25%, mechanism unclear).

chunks.title: Leukemoid Reaction vs CML
chunks.text: Chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) typically presents with the entire spectrum of maturing granulocytic cells (bands, metamyelocytes, myelocytes, promyelocytes, blasts) in the peripheral blood. CML should be considered when WBC >50 × 10⁹/L is unexplained, especially if persistent. Key distinguishing features: in CML — basophilia is common, LAP (leukocyte alkaline phosphatase) score is low, BCR-ABL1 fusion gene is present on cytogenetics/FISH/PCR. In leukemoid reaction — LAP score is elevated, BCR-ABL1 is absent, clinical context shows infection/inflammation, neutrophilia often decreases with treatment of underlying cause. Other myeloproliferative neoplasms (polycythemia vera, essential thrombocythemia, myelofibrosis) can also cause neutrophilia. JAK2 V617F mutation testing is indicated when MPN is suspected.

chunks.title: Neutropenia - Definition and Severity
chunks.text: Neutropenia is defined as an ANC less than 1.8 × 10⁹/L (some use <2.0). Severity classification: mild neutropenia (ANC 1.0-1.8): low infection risk; moderate neutropenia (ANC 0.5-1.0): significant infection risk; severe neutropenia (ANC <0.5): high risk for life-threatening bacterial and fungal infections; agranulocytosis (ANC ~0): extreme risk. Severe neutropenia requires urgent evaluation, blood cultures if febrile, and consideration of empiric broad-spectrum antibiotics. Absolute neutrophil count calculation: ANC = WBC × (% neutrophils + % bands)/100. Note that benign ethnic neutropenia (BEN) is more common in African and Middle Eastern populations, where neutrophil counts of 1.0-1.8 are normal variants not associated with infection risk.

chunks.title: Causes of Neutropenia
chunks.text: Causes of neutropenia by category: Drug-induced (most common): chemotherapy, clozapine, propylthiouracil, carbimazole, chloramphenicol, sulfasalazine, gold, dapsone, ticlopidine. Infections: viral (EBV, CMV, HIV, influenza, parvovirus B19), sepsis (consumption), malaria. Autoimmune: primary autoimmune neutropenia, SLE, Felty syndrome (RA + splenomegaly + neutropenia), Sjögren syndrome. Congenital/hereditary: Kostmann syndrome (severe congenital neutropenia, ELA2 mutation), cyclic neutropenia (regular 21-day cycles, ELA2 mutation), benign ethnic neutropenia. Bone marrow disorders: aplastic anemia (pancytopenia), MDS, leukemia, lymphoma, marrow infiltration, vitamin B12/folate deficiency. Hypersplenism: portal hypertension, storage diseases, Gaucher disease.

chunks.title: Thrombocytopenia - Differential Diagnosis
chunks.text: Thrombocytopenia (platelet count <150 × 10⁹/L) differential diagnosis: Pseudothrombocytopenia: EDTA-induced platelet clumping (most common spurious cause) — repeat in citrate tube, examine smear for aggregates. Immune thrombocytopenia (ITP): most common immune cause; anti-platelet antibodies destroy platelets; isolated thrombocytopenia with normal WBC/Hgb. Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT): typically 50% drop in platelets 5-14 days after heparin exposure; paradoxically prothrombotic. TTP: microangiopathic hemolytic anemia + thrombocytopenia + schistocytes on smear + elevated LDH. DIC: elevated PT/PTT, low fibrinogen, elevated D-dimer. Drug-induced: quinine, sulfonamides, gold, rifampicin, checkpoint inhibitors. Liver disease/hypersplenism: platelet sequestration. Marrow failure: aplastic anemia, MDS, leukemia — associated pancytopenia.

chunks.title: Thrombocytosis - Reactive vs Clonal
chunks.text: Thrombocytosis (platelet count >400 × 10⁹/L). Reactive (secondary) thrombocytosis is far more common than clonal causes: iron deficiency (most common cause in children), infections/inflammatory states, post-splenectomy, tissue damage (surgery, trauma), malignancy, medications. Reactive thrombocytosis rarely exceeds 1000 × 10⁹/L and typically resolves with treatment of underlying cause. Essential thrombocythemia (ET) and other myeloproliferative neoplasms (polycythemia vera, CML) cause clonal thrombocytosis. Suspected when: persistent thrombocytosis >600 × 10⁹/L, no clear reactive cause, associated with other CBC abnormalities. Workup: JAK2 V617F mutation (present in ~50% ET, ~95% PV), CALR mutation (~25% ET), MPL mutation (~5% ET), bone marrow biopsy.

chunks.title: CBC Patterns in Primary Immunodeficiency Disorders
chunks.text: The CBC with differential and blood smear provides valuable information about the cellular immune system in evaluating for primary immunodeficiency disorders (PID). Key CBC findings that suggest PID: lymphopenia (ALC <1.0 × 10⁹/L) — red flag for cellular immunodeficiency, especially SCID; severe neutropenia (ANC <0.5) — may indicate congenital neutropenia; pancytopenia — bone marrow failure syndromes (aplastic anemia, dyskeratosis congenita); in males, thrombocytopenia with small platelets (low MPV) suggests Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome. CBC alone cannot diagnose most PIDs but identifies patterns requiring further investigation. An apparently normal CBC does not exclude antibody deficiencies (XLA, CVID, IgA deficiency) where lymphocyte counts may be normal.

chunks.title: Lymphopenia and Combined Immunodeficiency
chunks.text: Lymphopenia (ALC <1.0 × 10⁹/L in adults, age-adjusted in children) is a significant red flag for primary immunodeficiency. The definition depends on age — values normal for adults may be critically low for infants. Persistent lymphopenia requires: flow cytometry for lymphocyte subsets (CD3/CD4/CD8 T cells, CD19 B cells, CD16+56 NK cells), immunoglobulin levels (IgG, IgA, IgM). SCID (severe combined immunodeficiency): profound lymphopenia in infancy, absent T cells ± B cells, recurrent life-threatening infections, failure to thrive. DiGeorge syndrome (22q11.2 deletion): T cell lymphopenia (primarily), associated with conotruncal cardiac defects, hypocalcemia (hypoparathyroidism), characteristic facies. Treatment for SCID: hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (curative).

chunks.title: Antibody Deficiency Disorders
chunks.text: Antibody deficiency disorders: X-linked agammaglobulinemia (XLA): absent B cells (CD19 count ~0), profound hypogammaglobulinemia (IgG <100 mg/dL), recurrent serious bacterial infections starting at 6-9 months (when maternal antibodies wane); CBC shows normal WBC and neutrophils but absent B cell fraction on flow cytometry. Common Variable Immunodeficiency (CVID): most common symptomatic antibody deficiency; low IgG plus low IgA or IgM; normal B cell numbers but impaired function; presents in adults with recurrent sinopulmonary infections, autoimmune manifestations, malignancy risk. Selective IgA deficiency: most common PID; usually asymptomatic; risk of anaphylaxis with blood transfusions (anti-IgA antibodies). Evaluate antibody function by measuring vaccine responses (protein and polysaccharide antigens).

chunks.title: Phagocytic and NK Cell Disorders
chunks.text: Phagocytic disorders: Chronic Granulomatous Disease (CGD): failure of oxidative burst; recurrent bacterial and fungal infections with catalase-positive organisms (Staph aureus, Aspergillus); CBC often shows neutrophilia during infections. Leukocyte Adhesion Deficiency (LAD): neonates present with delayed umbilical cord separation, persistent severe neutrophilia (WBC >20 without infection), severe recurrent skin and mucosal infections; diagnosed by CD18 expression on flow cytometry. Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome (WAS): X-linked; classic triad of thrombocytopenia (small platelets, low MPV) + eczema + recurrent infections; CBC shows low platelet count with characteristically small platelets (MPV <7 fL); WAS protein mutation confirms diagnosis. NK cell deficiency: recurrent severe herpesvirus infections; CD16+56 cells absent or <100 cells/microL.

chunks.title: Erythrocytosis - Classification and Workup
chunks.text: Erythrocytosis (increased red blood cell mass) is defined as Hgb >17.5 g/dL or HCT >53% in males and Hgb >15.5 g/dL or HCT >46% in females (or elevated RBC mass on isotope dilution studies). Classification: Relative (spurious) polycythemia: plasma volume reduction with normal RBC mass (dehydration, burns, diuresis). Absolute erythrocytosis: secondary — hypoxia-driven EPO elevation (COPD, sleep apnea, high altitude, cyanotic heart disease), EPO-secreting tumors (renal cell carcinoma, hepatocellular carcinoma), CO poisoning. Primary (polycythemia vera, PV): JAK2 V617F mutation (>95% cases), panmyelosis (elevated RBC + WBC + platelets), splenomegaly. Workup: oxygen saturation, serum EPO level (low in PV, elevated in secondary), JAK2 V617F mutation testing, bone marrow biopsy if PV suspected.

chunks.title: Eosinophilia - Causes and Evaluation
chunks.text: Eosinophilia is defined as absolute eosinophil count >0.5 × 10⁹/L. Hypereosinophilia: AEC >1.5 × 10⁹/L — requires evaluation for end-organ damage (cardiac, pulmonary, cutaneous, neurological). Hypereosinophilic syndrome (HES): eosinophilia >1.5 for >1 month with organ involvement. Causes (NAADAD mnemonic): Neoplastic (lymphoma, leukemia, myeloproliferative), Allergic (asthma, atopic dermatitis, drug hypersensitivity), Adrenal insufficiency, Dermatologic (bullous pemphigoid, psoriasis), Autoimmune (IBD, eosinophilic GI disorders), Drugs (antibiotics, NSAIDs, anticonvulsants, allopurinol). Parasitic infections (Toxocara, Strongyloides, Ascaris, filariasis) are common in travelers/immigrants. Workup: stool ova and parasites (3 specimens), serum IgE level, echocardiogram and troponin if HES, chest X-ray, consider IL-5 pathway testing for clonal eosinophilia.

chunks.title: Lymphocytosis - Reactive vs Malignant
chunks.text: Lymphocytosis is defined as ALC >4.8 × 10⁹/L. Reactive lymphocytosis: viral infections — EBV (infectious mononucleosis: atypical lymphocytes, positive monospot/Paul-Bunnell, hepatosplenomegaly), CMV, HIV acute, hepatitis, pertussis (markedly elevated with immature-appearing lymphocytes). Characterized by atypical lymphocytes on smear, usually self-limited. CLL (Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia): most common adult leukemia; monoclonal lymphocytosis >5 × 10⁹/L of mature-appearing small lymphocytes; CD5+/CD19+/CD23+/CD20-dim on flow cytometry; smear shows smudge cells. Monoclonal B cell lymphocytosis (MBL): <5 × 10⁹/L with CLL-phenotype cells — low risk of progression. Workup for lymphocytosis >5 × 10⁹/L: peripheral blood flow cytometry, LDH, β2-microglobulin, EBV/CMV serology.

chunks.title: Lymphopenia - Acquired Causes
chunks.text: Acquired lymphopenia (ALC <1.0 × 10⁹/L in adults) has many causes. Infections: HIV/AIDS (CD4+ T cell depletion; CD4 <200/microL defines AIDS), severe sepsis, COVID-19, influenza, hepatitis, EBV. Medications: corticosteroids (redistribute lymphocytes to marrow), immunosuppressants (cyclosporine, tacrolimus, mycophenolate), chemotherapy, rituximab (CD19 B cell depletion), alemtuzumab. Autoimmune: SLE, RA, Sjögren syndrome. Radiation therapy. Malnutrition and protein deficiency. Intestinal lymphangiectasia (lymphocyte loss into gut). Note: while reactive causes are common, persistent lymphopenia (especially with CD4 <200) warrants HIV testing and evaluation for other immunodeficiency.

chunks.title: When to Request a Blood Smear
chunks.text: A peripheral blood smear should be reviewed when: any CBC parameter is flagged as abnormal, there are instrument flags for abnormal cells (blasts, atypical lymphocytes, immature granulocytes), suspected hematologic malignancy, suspected hemolytic anemia (to look for schistocytes, spherocytes, sickle cells), unexplained pancytopenia, unexpected thrombocytopenia (to rule out pseudothrombocytopenia), suspected microangiopathic process (TTP/HUS), or to confirm automated differential. Flagged samples should be reviewed by medical technologists, and a subset by hematopathologists. Key findings: blasts (acute leukemia), schistocytes (TMA — TTP, HUS, DIC), hypersegmented neutrophils (megaloblastic), Howell-Jolly bodies (asplenia), target cells (liver disease, thalassemia, HbC), teardrop cells (myelofibrosis).

chunks.title: Sickle Cell Disease - CBC Features
chunks.text: Sickle cell disease (HbSS) CBC features: chronic hemolytic anemia (Hgb typically 6-9 g/dL), elevated reticulocyte count (reflecting compensatory erythropoiesis), sickle cells and target cells on peripheral smear, elevated bilirubin and LDH, low haptoglobin. Baseline MCV may be normal or elevated (due to reticulocytosis). During vaso-occlusive crisis: no characteristic change in CBC but pain crisis triggers leukocytosis. Aplastic crisis (usually from parvovirus B19): sudden drop in Hgb with very low reticulocyte count. Splenic sequestration crisis: acute fall in Hgb with enlarged spleen. Diagnosis: hemoglobin electrophoresis (HbS >90% in HbSS, HbS + HbC in HbSC, HbS + HbA in HbAS trait). Newborn screening identifies SCD before symptoms.

chunks.title: TTP and HUS - CBC Clues
chunks.text: Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP) and hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) are thrombotic microangiopathies (TMA) with characteristic CBC findings. TTP CBC: thrombocytopenia (often <20 × 10⁹/L), microangiopathic hemolytic anemia with schistocytes (fragmented RBCs) on peripheral smear, elevated LDH (often >10× normal), normal or slightly elevated creatinine (HUS shows more renal involvement). Classic pentad (now rare): MAHA + thrombocytopenia + fever + neurological symptoms + renal dysfunction. ADAMTS13 activity <10% confirms TTP. DIC: similar CBC (thrombocytopenia + schistocytes) but also shows prolonged PT/PTT, low fibrinogen, elevated D-dimer — distinguishes from TTP.

chunks.title: Anemia in Pregnancy
chunks.text: Anemia in pregnancy is defined as Hgb <11 g/dL in first and third trimesters, <10.5 g/dL in second trimester (due to physiologic hemodilution with plasma expansion). Physiologic anemia of pregnancy: plasma volume increases ~50%, RBC mass increases ~25% — relative dilutional effect. Most common cause of true anemia: iron deficiency (increased iron demand for fetal development, expanded RBC mass, blood loss at delivery). Features: low MCV, low MCH, elevated RDW, low ferritin. Folate deficiency also common, especially if dietary intake poor or multiple gestation. Routine screening: CBC at first prenatal visit and 28 weeks. Postpartum: CBC to evaluate blood loss anemia. Treatment: oral iron supplementation for IDA; folate supplementation (also prevents neural tube defects).

chunks.title: CBC Methodology - Modern Analyzers
chunks.text: Modern hematology analyzers use impedance-based methods (Coulter principle), optical light scatter, and fluorescence to count and characterize blood cells. The Coulter principle: cells passing through an electrically charged aperture cause resistance changes proportional to cell volume. Light scattering: cells hydrodynamically focused in a flow cell are illuminated by laser; light scattered at different angles provides information on cell size, complexity, and contents. Five-part WBC differential uses combinations of DC impedance, radiofrequency conductivity, light scatter, peroxidase staining, and fluorescent RNA/DNA dyes. Flags for abnormal WBCs indicate cells at the monocyte/neutrophil interface (BLAST flag), large lymphoid cells (ATYPICAL LYMPH flag), or neutrophil left shift. Flagged samples require review of peripheral blood smear.

chunks.title: CBC in Neonates and Infants
chunks.text: CBC normal values vary significantly by age in neonates and infants. Neonates (0-2 weeks): Hgb 14-22 g/dL (polycythemia is normal), MCV 95-121 fL (macrocytic — HbF is larger), nucleated RBCs are normal in first few days. Physiologic anemia of infancy: Hgb nadir at 6-12 weeks (Hgb ~9-11 g/dL) due to erythropoietin suppression after birth. Premature infants have a lower and earlier nadir. WBC in neonates is normally higher (9-30 × 10⁹/L), with neutrophil predominance at birth shifting to lymphocyte predominance by 2-4 weeks. Caution: lymphopenia in infants that appears 'normal' for adults may be severely low — age-specific normal values must be used, especially when evaluating for SCID or other primary immunodeficiencies.

chunks.title: MDS - CBC Features and Clues
chunks.text: Myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS) is a clonal bone marrow disorder causing cytopenias with dysplastic cell morphology. CBC clues for MDS: unexplained cytopenias (anemia ± neutropenia ± thrombocytopenia), macrocytosis (elevated MCV often >100 fL) despite normal B12/folate, elevated RDW, hypersegmented neutrophils, Pseudo-Pelger-Huet anomaly (bilobed neutrophils — 'pince-nez' cells), hyposegmented neutrophils, giant platelets or hypogranular platelets, monocytosis. Risk factors: prior chemotherapy, radiation, environmental exposures, advancing age (>60 years). Confirmation requires bone marrow biopsy showing dysplasia in ≥10% of cells in one or more lineages + cytogenetic abnormalities. Distinguished from B12/folate deficiency by normal B12/folate levels and characteristic dysplastic morphology.

chunks.title: Aplastic Anemia and Pancytopenia
chunks.text: Aplastic anemia is characterized by pancytopenia with a hypocellular bone marrow. CBC features: pancytopenia (anemia + neutropenia + thrombocytopenia), very low reticulocyte count (reticulocytopenia), low absolute reticulocyte count often <10 × 10⁹/L, normal to slightly elevated MCV. Severity defined by: severe (ANC <0.5, platelets <20, reticulocytes <1%) vs very severe (ANC <0.2). Causes: idiopathic (most common — immune-mediated T cell destruction of marrow), drugs (chloramphenicol, chemotherapy, carbimazole, gold), viral (EBV, CMV, hepatitis, parvovirus B19), PNH (paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria — clonal expansion), inherited (Fanconi anemia — hypersensitivity to DNA crosslinkers). Bone marrow biopsy is required: hypocellular marrow (<25% cellularity). Treatment: immunosuppression (ATG + cyclosporine) or allogeneic stem cell transplantation.

chunks.title: Benign Ethnic Neutropenia
chunks.text: Benign ethnic neutropenia (BEN) is a normal variant seen predominantly in individuals of African, Middle Eastern (particularly Yemenite Jewish), and West Indian descent. ANC typically ranges from 0.8-1.8 × 10⁹/L. Key characteristics: isolated neutropenia without anemia or thrombocytopenia, no increased susceptibility to infection (normal immune response), family history of low neutrophil counts, stability over time. BEN should be suspected in an asymptomatic patient from a high-prevalence population with mild neutropenia and an otherwise normal CBC. No treatment required; important to document to avoid unnecessary workup in the future. Evaluation: confirm no cytopenias in other cell lines, check family members, rule out drug causes, ensure no history of recurrent infections.

chunks.title: Immature Reticulocyte Fraction and Reticulocyte Indices
chunks.text: Modern analyzers provide reticulocyte indices beyond the standard reticulocyte count. Immature Reticulocyte Fraction (IRF): the proportion of reticulocytes with the highest RNA content (most immature); elevated IRF indicates increased marrow output and is the first parameter to change after erythropoietin administration or correction of deficiency. Reticulocyte Hemoglobin Content (CHr or RET-He on Sysmex): measures hemoglobin content of reticulocytes, which reflects iron availability for erythropoiesis in the past 3-4 days. CHr <26 pg is the earliest indicator of functional iron deficiency, preceding changes in ferritin, serum iron, or MCV. This is particularly useful in monitoring dialysis patients on EPO therapy and in diagnosing iron deficiency in inflammatory states where ferritin may be falsely elevated.

chunks.title: Leukemia - CBC Clues
chunks.text: Leukemia CBC patterns: Acute Leukemia (ALL/AML): variable WBC (may be low, normal, or very high), anemia, thrombocytopenia, blasts on peripheral smear (can be absent in aleukemic presentation), neutropenia. High WBC (>100 × 10⁹/L) with blasts suggests hyperleukocytosis — emergency (leukostasis risk). CML: markedly elevated WBC with entire granulocyte series (myelocytes, metamyelocytes, bands, blasts <10%), basophilia, thrombocytosis; BCR-ABL1 positive. CLL: lymphocytosis >5 × 10⁹/L of small mature lymphocytes, smudge cells on smear; flow cytometry confirms CD5+/CD19+/CD23+ phenotype. Multiple myeloma: CBC may show normocytic anemia, elevated ESR, rouleaux formation on smear (protein coating RBCs causing stacking), hyperviscosity symptoms.

chunks.title: Hemoglobin Variants and Electrophoresis Interpretation
chunks.text: Hemoglobin variants affect CBC interpretation. Normal adult hemoglobins: HbA (>95%), HbA2 (<3.5%), HbF (<1%). Beta-thalassemia trait: HbA2 3.5-7% (elevated), Hbf mildly elevated, low-normal Hgb, low MCV. HbS (sickle hemoglobin): HbSS (sickle cell disease), HbAS (trait — typically asymptomatic, normal CBC), HbSC (moderate severity). HbC: HbCC causes mild hemolytic anemia with target cells; HbAC trait is asymptomatic. Hemoglobin HPLC/electrophoresis is required for definitive characterization. Important CBC clue: an elevated HbA2 on electrophoresis in a patient with low MCV and normal ferritin strongly suggests beta-thalassemia trait. Hemoglobin variants can also interfere with point-of-care HbA1c measurements.

chunks.title: CBC Critical Values Requiring Urgent Action
chunks.text: CBC critical values requiring urgent clinical notification: Hemoglobin <7 g/dL: likely transfusion consideration (varies by clinical context); <6 g/dL is generally an emergency requiring transfusion. Platelets <20 × 10⁹/L: risk of spontaneous bleeding, including intracranial hemorrhage; platelets <10 × 10⁹/L require prophylactic transfusion. WBC >30 × 10⁹/L: consider infection vs malignancy; if blasts present, urgent hematology consult. WBC >100 × 10⁹/L with blasts: hyperleukocytosis — risk of leukostasis, medical emergency. ANC <0.5 × 10⁹/L with fever: febrile neutropenia — emergency requiring immediate blood cultures and broad-spectrum antibiotics. Hgb >20 g/dL: polycythemia vera or dehydration — risk of hyperviscosity and thrombosis.

chunks.title: Monocytosis and Monocytopenia
chunks.text: Monocytosis (absolute monocyte count >1.0 × 10⁹/L): Reactive causes: chronic infections especially mycobacterial (TB, atypical mycobacteria), fungal infections, SBE (subacute bacterial endocarditis), rickettsia, brucellosis. Autoimmune: SLE, IBD, rheumatoid arthritis, sarcoidosis. Post-chemotherapy recovery: first cell line to recover after marrow suppression. Hematologic malignancy: CMML (chronic myelomonocytic leukemia) — persistent monocytosis >1.0 × 10⁹/L for >3 months with dysplastic features and no BCR-ABL, must be excluded; AML-M5 (monocytic leukemia). Monocytopenia (<0.2 × 10⁹/L): rare, associated with HLH (hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis), aplastic anemia, or hairy cell leukemia (classic finding: monocytopenia + pancytopenia).

chunks.title: Basophilia
chunks.text: Basophilia (absolute basophil count >0.1 × 10⁹/L or basophils >1% of WBC) is most commonly associated with myeloproliferative neoplasms, particularly CML (where basophilia is a characteristic and diagnostically important finding). Other causes: allergic reactions, inflammatory bowel disease, hypothyroidism, iron deficiency, viral infections (varicella, smallpox). When basophilia is found unexpectedly, especially in conjunction with neutrophilia and thrombocytosis, evaluation for CML (BCR-ABL testing) is warranted. Extreme basophilia in CML can release histamine and cause peptic ulcer disease and pruritus.

chunks.title: Iron Studies Interpretation
chunks.text: Iron studies interpretation in anemia: Serum ferritin: most sensitive test for iron deficiency (<30 ng/mL diagnostic, <12 ng/mL specific). However, ferritin is an acute phase reactant — in inflammatory states (infection, cancer, liver disease), ferritin may be normal or elevated even with true iron deficiency (functional iron deficiency). Serum iron: reflects iron in transit; low in IDA and ACD; elevated in iron overload, hemolytic anemia. TIBC (Total Iron Binding Capacity): reflects transferrin level. Elevated in IDA (body produces more transferrin to capture iron); low in ACD, liver disease, protein malnutrition. Transferrin saturation (Fe/TIBC × 100): <20% in IDA; <20% in ACD; >45% in iron overload. In ambiguous cases (suspected IDA in inflammatory state), reticulocyte hemoglobin content (CHr) or bone marrow iron staining provides definitive assessment.
